schedule.class_attributes: SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy SDG-GE #13 Climate Action SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water SDG-GE #15 Life On Land English only Experiential Learning Course

courses.description: (UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001.) The course provides an interdisciplinary study of the Earth Systems, including natural phenomena in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere. The mechanism of these systems, associated dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced and discussed. The course also serves as a platform to understand and critically assess global environmental change, natural hazards, biodiversity loss, and the water-energy-food nexus, and explore potential technological and policy solutions to these problems. These objectives align strongly with the understanding and pursuit of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life Below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land. In addition to attending lectures, students will visit the Jockey Club Museum of Climate Change where it displays the way scientists examine past and current climate and the factors leading to current global temperature change. A geological field excursion will be another highlight of the course to demonstrate the scientific concepts applied to reveal Earth’s tectonic history, evolution and interaction among various spheres. With diverse scientific topics in Earth’s systems, the course shows students how each Earth’s system is interlocking with other spheres and, hence raise the awareness in the importance of sustainability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC1000.

courses.description: The Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences is a project-based learning experience designed to introduce freshmen to Earth and Environmental Sciences through direct field observation and hands-on project work. This course will be led by 3 instructors in Geology and Geophysics, Atmospheric Sciences and Environmental Sciences. By exploring the geology beneath our feet, the atmospheric currents above us, and the environmental issues that surround us, students will gain a holistic understanding of our planet.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Fundamental Earth and Environmental Field Study I
courses.description: EESC2009 is a fundamental field-based course introducing elementary concepts of past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. It also covers important aspects of plate tectonics, different rock types, geological deformation, geomorphology and environmental changes, natural hazards and human impacts. The principal goal of this course is to let students understand how the present geological records and landforms reveal the past tectonic movements and affect the human urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features, with the help of field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer and GPS receiver). Basic skills of field techniques, interpreting geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to assist students acquiring field data and discuss possible geologic processes. A field report from each group is required to summarize the field study logically. Field locations of this course may change from year to year. All students are welcome, but priority will be given to students who have taken EESC1001.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC2110 or ESSC2110.

courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the solid earth system stressing the geological, chemical, physical, and biological interactions among the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical concepts to explain the history and behaviour of the solid earth system. Geophysical and geochemical techniques for probing the interior of the earth are reviewed. Plate tectonics is introduced as a unifying theme to understand geodynamic processes. The course includes discussions of topics that are relevant to society, resources and sustainability, such as the physical and chemical basis of natural hazards (earthquakes, tsunami, landslides) and their mitigation, and the impact of geological processes on the global environment.

courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the climate system, stressing the dynamics of the atmosphere and its physical and chemical interactions with the hydrosphere, biosphere and geosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical principles to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards (e.g., typhoons, floods), and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence. Topics include Earth’s energy balance, climate feedback, convection and clouds, general circulation of the atmosphere and ocean, biogeochemistry and global carbon cycle, roles of vegetation and ecosystems, and historical and future climate change. Student taking this course are expected to have taken PHYS1111, CHEM1070 and MATH1010 or equivalent.

courses.description: This course covers basic computation skills which are important to modern Earth and Environmental Sciences research and data analysis. Topics include the basic Python language syntax; programming flow control; usage of functions; file input/output modules; data visualisation; atmospheric science applications; geoscience applications and basic machine learning applications in earth and environmental sciences. Python 3 will be used throughout the course. Examples and tutorials will be based on various problems in Earth and Environmental Sciences using actual observational or in-situ data.

courses.description: Field study of current landform and geological features is the key to reveal past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. This also provides data for further studies on natural hazards. EESC2119 is an intermediate level, field-based course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of atmospheric sciences, plate tectonics, volcanoes, deformation structures, sedimentology, coastal features, earthquakes and associated present-day infrastructures. The principal goal of this course is to let students study major atmospheric sciences, geological features and understand how tectonic movement and atmospheric phenomenon contribute to the current different landforms, disasters and urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features. Basic skills of using field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer), studying geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to help students acquire field data and analyze possible atmospheric phenomenon and geologic processes. A field report is required to summarize the field study logically. The field location and term of offer of this course may change from year to year. Due to limited quota, priority will be given to students who have taken EESC2010 and passed the pre-enrolment quiz.

courses.description: EESC2129 is designed to provide students with fundamental geological field techniques and the application of geological and environmental concepts specific to the region of Hong Kong. The course aims to deepen students' understanding of the local geology, including its formation processes, tectonic history, and its relationship with the environment. By the end of the course, students will have acquired a solid background in local geology and geomorphology. The course emphasizes hands-on training and practical skills development. Students will learn essential geological field techniques, including map reading, gathering geological data, making field observations, and jotting geological field notes. They will also develop critical thinking skills through the analysis and interpretation of geological data. Additionally, the course includes training in life-saving skills to ensure students' safety during fieldwork. EESC2129 consists of a 10-day local field study and five pre-trip lectures. The field study provides an immersive experience where students will directly apply the knowledge and techniques learned in the classroom to real geological settings in Hong Kong. The pre-trip lectures serve as a preparatory phase, covering relevant theoretical concepts, field methodologies, and safety protocols. Following the field study, two post-trip discussions will provide an opportunity for students to share their findings, and engage in further analysis and interpretation. Successful completion of EESC2129 requires continuous teamwork and independent assignments. Students will be expected to collaborate with their peers during fieldwork, share responsibilities, and contribute to group discussions. Additionally, independent assignments will be assigned to reinforce students' understanding of the course material and encourage individual exploration of specific geological topics.Note: This course may involve physical activities and fieldwork in outdoor environments. Students are advised to comply with safety guidelines, follow instructions from instructors, and maintain appropriate fitness levels to ensure a safe and enriching learning experience.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and with instructor's approval.

courses.description: EESC2160 is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of minerals as fundamental building blocks of the Earth, their chemistry, occurrence, physical and chemical features, crystallography, as well as the formation and uses of naturally formed minerals, oil, and gas. The course also covers mining processes and management, exploring the interaction between natural resources and the environment, and their impact on the biological system. The course teaches students chemistry in the Solid Earth, occurrence, exploration and usage of natural resources like minerals, gas and oil. The course trains students with skills of identifying physical properties and chemical properties of natural forming minerals. Teachers will introduce techniques and technology in mining and extracting natural resources. Areas of interaction between natural resources and the environment, as well as the management of natural resources, will be elaborated in student’s problem-based learning sessions. Students are expected to equip knowledge and skills in understanding the real-world scenarios of the natural resources, and problem-solving skills in resource management practices and decision-making processes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010

courses.description: This course deals with the relationships between living organisms, resources and environment. The basic multidisciplinary concepts of sustainable development, human population and health risk, conservation of resources, climate change, environmental degradation, pollution control, biodiversity, solid waste and waste water management, etc, will be introduced. Concepts of think globally, act locally will be introduced the importance of acting as a global citizen to help solving environmental problems with an innovative mind to design new policy or technology. Case studies and field trips are included to illustrate various environmental issues using a multidisciplinary approach with emphasis on how modern technology can have significant societal impacts and responsibility.

courses.description: This is a foundation course designed to equip students with a proper understanding of the fundamental aspects of environmental chemistry. It introduces the basic concept of chemical equilibrium and kinetics, the nature and characteristics of various common types of air and water pollution arising from industrial, agricultural and domestic sources. It outlines the principles of measurement for various parameters commonly used for air and water pollution studies, their significance and limitations. It also examines various types of aerial emission arising from combustion and industrial processes, and vehicles, and their chemical interaction leading to various global environmental issues such as the formation of photochemical smog, depletion of ozone layer and global warming effects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC2515. Pre-requisite: EESC2270 or ENSC2270 or permission of the instructor.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Environmental Chemistry Laboratory

meetings.instructor: Dr. LO Chui Man,   Professor LEE Hung Kay

courses.description: This is a foundation chemistry laboratory course designed to accompany EESC2515. This course illustrates the fundamental principles and basic techniques in general environmental chemistry. Laboratory work covers a range of experiments, including acid-base reactions, chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, complexation equilibria, coordination chemistry of the transition metals, and analysis of air pollutants. Students who finish this course are expected to be familiar with the general techniques in conducting chemistry experiments and the use of simple instruments such as IR and UV–Vis spectrophotometers. They will also learn how to design of experiments and report experimental data in scientific reports. The assessment scheme of this course is based on students' performance in conducting experiments and report writing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC2517. Co-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515 or permission of the instructor.

courses.description: The course provides a survey of elementary analytical quantitative and qualitative methods commonly used in earth and environmental sciences, with applications in geophysics, geophysical/environmental fluid dynamics, as well as related aspects in thermodynamics and wave physics. Teaching aided by numerical programming is adopted and emphasized, in addition to analytical understanding of these methods. Typical examples include heat conduction on earth surface, seismic and ocean waves, air pollution, geodynamics, and atmospheric dynamics.

courses.description: This is a multidisciplinary course introducing the fundamental physical, chemical and biological principles necessary for understanding the natural and built environments, with an emphasis on reliable water and food supplies, pollution mitigation, waste management, energy resources, climate change, and sustainable development. Examples of engineering solutions to tackle some of these resource and environmental issues are presented. Field trips are included to illustrate interesting case studies. Topics include: conservation principles for mass, energy and momentum in the environmental systems; basic environmental chemistry, hydrology and ecology; risk assessment; and basic principles of water resource engineering, solid waste treatment, noise pollution, air pollution control, climate change adaptation and mitigation, and the interplay between energy consumption and the environment.

courses.title: Environmental Sciences Field Study I
courses.description: This intensive 1-2 week, 1 credit course provides a unique opportunity for students to go on a comprehensive field trip to Southeast Asia or Belt and Road countries. The journey is designed to offer students a firsthand understanding of environmental sciences and the pressing issues that are currently shaping its discourse. Students will engage in an immersive ecotour, visiting diverse ecosystems, conservation sites, and areas grappling with environmental challenges. The trip aims to expose students to the realities of environmental science, allowing them to witness the dynamic interplay of ecological, socio-political, and economic factors that influence environmental policies and practices.

courses.description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the processes and products of rock deformation in three dimensions, ranging from micro- (micron) to macro- (kilometer) scales. It discusses geometries and mechanism of faults, folds, structural features of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks, and superposed deformations and introduces regional deformational history and tectonics. Structural geology in the field of resource exploration (petroleum and mineral deposits) is also introduced. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise and demonstrations as well as field trips to local or overseas outcrops.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3100. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geoscience Field Course
courses.description: Understanding of Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time is highly dependent upon the experience and capabilities gained through doing fieldwork. EESC3110 is an intermediate level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic petrology, tectonics, geophysics and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their geometries in three dimensions, and understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanism. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e. Compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques of field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes (relatively occurring on short geological time scale), which are of environmental and ecological importance. The field location (either in mainland of China or overseas) may change from year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC3110. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010), and (EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120) or by instructor’s approval.

courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts of the physics of the Earth to understand how the solid Earth works. Since 1960s, plate tectonics has been developed to explain observations on Earth such as mountain building, occurrence of earthquakes and volcanoes, as well as deposition of natural resources. The discovery of plate tectonics requires understanding of geophysical methods, which will be covered in this course. The topics covered include the Earth’s gravitational and magnetic fields, earthquake seismology, internal structure of the Earth, thermal and electrical properties, as well as geodynamics. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced.

courses.description: This course that will be offered in the summer term aims to develop the students’ knowledge, skills, and interest in seismology, scientific computing, and seismic data processing. Topics include introduction to Linux command line, shell scripting, and Generic Mapping Tools (GMT); introduction to Seismic Analysis Code (SAC); how to use the various Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) tools for data request and initial data exploration; and various methods to model and visualize seismic waveforms for earthquake and velocity structure studies.

courses.description: EESC3140 is designed to introduce students to the global distribution of elements and the chemistry of natural Earth's materials. The course focuses on understanding the chemical processes operating within the solid Earth and other planets, spanning from the past to the present. Emphasis is placed on developing quantitative and analytical skills in geochemistry. The course covers a wide range of topics, including fundamental principles of geochemical processes, thermal dynamics, phase transitions and the relationship between pressure, temperature, and composition in different geological materials, major elements, trace elements, rare Earth elements, element mobility and mineral stability, and the roles of different elements in Earth’s evolution. The course also introduces the role of minerals and rocks in supporting and influencing life and, how biological processes affect the chemical composition of Earth’s atmosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere. Students will be trained to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the formation and interaction of materials within the Earth. Students will learn about the geochemical processes involved and their implications for potential tectonic settings and surficial processes. By studying geochemical data and engaging in practical sessions, students will develop the skills to analyze and interpret the geochemical data, allowing them to discuss paleo-environments with possible tectonic models such as seafloor spreading, subduction and mountain building regimes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) or (EESC2130 or ESSC2130 or EESC2119 or EESC2129) or (EESC3100 or ESSC3100)

courses.description: This course introduces observations of and physical principles governing the circulation of the Earth’s atmosphere in relation to weather and climate. The topics covered include atmospheric composition and structure, convection, fundamentals of atmospheric motions, and the basic principles for weather and climate modeling. Physical principles covered include basic conservation laws, balanced flows, atmospheric thermodynamics, circulation and vorticity, atmospheric waves, and theories for various weather systems.

courses.description: Environmental Microbiology is an interdisciplinary course that explores the fascinating world of microorganisms and their impact on the environment. This comprehensive course covers both the scientific fundamentals and practical applications in the field of Environmental Microbiology. This course will begin with an introduction to the field by covering topics such as the formation of the biosphere, and the science of cell biology. Then the course goes beyond theory and delves into the methods used in environmental microbiology to study microorganisms in their natural habitats. They will also examine the applications of environmental microbiology, such as studying the role of bacteria in climate change, biodegradation, and bioremediation. These practical applications highlight how microorganisms can be harnessed to address environmental challenges and contribute to a sustainable future.

courses.description: The course introduces various types of chemical contaminants and their adverse effects on animals, humans and ecosystems, and environmental management strategies. It provides an overview of ecotoxicology principles, sources, chemical nature, fate of contaminants, and their interaction and impacts with the ecosystem, and the living organisms in the environment. It also relates ecotoxicology to risk assessment including assessment, monitoring, management and protection of the environment from toxicants.Students will gain insights into the impacts of pollutants on aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. They will also delve into sustainable environmental management strategies, including pollution prevention, remediation, and ecological risk assessments.

courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological principles governing the functioning of terrestrial and marine ecosystems, and their roles in shaping the Earth’s climatic and geological environments. Topics include: basic hydrology and surface energy balance; energy, momentum, water and chemical exchange between ecosystems and the atmosphere; cycling of water, carbon and other nutrients in soil, vegetation and ocean; survival strategies of different life forms (especially plants and microorganisms); ecosystem structures and functions; landscapes, disturbances and ecosystem dynamics; human perturbations of biogeochemical cycles via pollution, greenhouse gas emissions and land use; responses and evolution of terrestrial and marine ecosystems under global climate change. This course serves as a comprehensive introduction to ecological climatology, biogeochemistry and ecosystem ecology, and requires basic mathematical operations. This version of the course includes an integrated set of computer laboratory sessions.

courses.description: This course includes the science behind the global warming issue, how the public views the issue and the critical thinking needed to analyze the evidence seen in the media/articles from the point of view of scientists. The world energy use, which is considered to be the cause of global warming, and the impacts are discussed in the course. In this course, students will learn about the radiation budgets/balance in the atmosphere, possible climate forcings that can upset the energy balance, how the earth’s global average temperature is measured, why global warming is described as “the biggest hoax” in human history, observations from the ocean and cryosphere and popular environmental issues/arguments discussed in the mainstream media. Newest observations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report are included throughout the course.This course actively incorporates elements of innovation, design, global citizenship and social enterprisingness by asking the students to think innovatively but critically about possible solutions to adapt to and combat climate change and the global energy/health crisis. Different options including their pros and cons are actively discussed in class. Students are encouraged to think creatively about the problem from different angles, e.g., by standing in the shoes of climate skeptics – evaluating their “data”, how they present them, the arguments put forth by them – in order to develop a strategic approach to best communicate the issues to a variety of stakeholders. Project assignments will allow students to focus on one particular environmental issue in other part of the world, attempting to address the issue in the very different geographical, cultural, economic and political contexts from that of the students. Example projects can be “How to use geoengineering to combat climate change?”, “How can Sub-Saharan Africa secure its future food supply under the threat of climate change?”, etc. In the course, students will define and understand the problem. They shall form groups and discuss their own point of views and search information on the evidence of the corresponding arguments. They will present their ideas in class and write a self-reflection report. Each of the group will have to make an “infographic”- a layout of science knowledge learnt in the project that is easy enough for the public to understand but at the same time informative. Good infographics will be used in our OpenDay.

courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth and environmental sciences applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Advanced Geosciences Field Study I
courses.description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC4119 is an advanced-level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC3110 or ESSC3110. Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and [(EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120)], or by instructor’s approval.
courses.component: Field Studies/Field-trip Lecture Project Interactive Tutorial

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth and Environmental Sciences because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4120. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Advanced Geosciences Field Study II
courses.description: EESC4129 is a comprehensive course designed to provide students with a deep understanding of plate tectonics, advanced geological field techniques, and their applications in engineering and water resources. The course aims to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of plate tectonics, including sea floor spreading, subduction, and mineral deposits. Additionally, it focuses on teaching students advanced geological field techniques and their practical application in field studies. The course also addresses engineering problems related to geological factors and explores the significance of water resources within a geological context. EESC4129 incorporates a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical training. The course includes 10 lectures covering essential concepts and techniques, plus 14 days in the field and engage in onsite discussions. Students will have the opportunity to visit a geologically significant area to gain firsthand experience and understanding of the geological setting, formation processes, tectonic history, and their relationship with urban planning. This field study will provide students with a solid background in local geology and geomorphology, enabling them to comprehend the geological processes and their implications in various settings. Students will engage in a mapping exercise, where they will collect geological data, perform detailed field observations, and analyze their findings. This exercise will enhance their critical thinking skills and equip them with the ability to plan geological projects effectively. Additionally, students will receive training in life-saving skills to ensure their safety during fieldwork. By the end of the course, students will have developed a heightened awareness of the interplay between geology and urban planning, contributing to their holistic understanding of the natural environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) or (EESC2119 or EESC2129) or EESC2160 or (EESC3100 or ESSC3100) or EESC3140 or (EESC4120 or ESSC4120) or with course coordinator’s approval

courses.description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer simulation. The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4130. Pre-requisite: EESC3100 or ESSC3100.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4140. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or ESSC3010.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Volcanoes
courses.description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Marine Geology and Geophysics
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of marine geology and geophysics. Marine geology is distinct from that of continent and is the important foundation to launch Plate Tectonics, the modern unified theory of the Earth. In this course, major components of marine geological settings such as mid-ocean ridges, transform faults, subduction zones, oceanic lithosphere, and etc. will be introduced and discussed in details. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced. Field experiments of scientific instruments such as Ocean Bottom Seismometers, marine magnetometer and gravimeter will be conducted. A geological field trip will also be included. This course will be jointly offered with Ocean College, Zhejiang University, as an initiative to develop ocean sciences at CUHK.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4160. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or ESSC3010 or (EESC4010 or ESSC4010).
courses.component: Field Studies/Field-trip Lecture Project Interactive Tutorial

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: What is the mechanism of plate tectonics and a variety of geological phenomena, such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting? Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. Lectures, paper discussions, and tutorials will help you to understand the principle of geodynamics, learn how to develop simple but useful models, and explain how the Earth evolves.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.

courses.title: Earthquake Source Physics

courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of earthquake source physics. The topics covered include seismic instrumentation, geophysical observations of earthquake source processes, kinematic source representation of earthquakes, dynamic rupture propagation of earthquakes, frictional properties of fault zones, and entire earthquake cycle. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4180. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or (EESC4010 or ESSC4010) or (EESC4140 or ESSC4140).

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Boundary-Layer Meteorology

meetings.instructor: Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald

courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; boundary layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4210. Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) or (EESC3200 or ESSC3200) or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Tropical Meteorology

meetings.instructor: Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Professor TAM Chi Yung Francis

courses.description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, tropical ocean circulation, tropical weather, climate and atmosphere-ocean interaction phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4220. Pre-requisite: EESC3200 or ESSC3200.

courses.description: Fundamentals of aerosol physics and chemistry; condensation and evaporation; thermodynamics; nucleation, diffusion, coagulation; radiative, hygroscopic properties, and cloud formation potential of aerosols; aerosol phase oxidation reactions; heterogeneous oxidative processes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4230. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
courses.description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4240.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: General Circulation and Climate Models
courses.description: This course is about the general circulation of the atmosphere, oceans, and the interactions among them and with other components of the Earth System, as well as their simulations using climate models, in the context of climate variability and climate change. Topics include basic fluid dynamics of large-scale atmospheric and oceanic motions, radiative transfer, atmospheric general circulation, midlatitude dynamics, ocean general circulation, and general circulation models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4250. Pre-requisite: EESC3200 or ESSC3200 or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Urban Climatology
courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4260. Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Cloud Dynamics

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo
Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo
Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo

courses.description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere. Student taking this course are expected to have taken EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Meteorology
courses.description: Practical Meteorology is an advanced undergraduate course designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of meteorology and their practical applications. The course will cover synoptic and mesoscale meteorology, satellite and radar meteorology, radiative transfer, lidar meteorology, aviation meteorology, and atmospheric instrumentation. Through a combination of lectures and case studies using instrument data, students will gain hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting meteorological data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Advanced Environmental Chemistry

meetings.instructor: Dr. CHAN Ka Long Donald

courses.description: This course is designed to extend students' understanding of and develop their ability in the application of various aspects of environmental chemistry in relation to the major types of air and water pollution associated with industrial and vehicle emissions. It outlines the basic processes in bleaching and dyeing, electroplating and food processing that give rise to water pollution and application of physico-chemical techniques in controlling such pollution. It also examines combustion processes and the associated applications and limitations of the absorption, adsorption, oxidation-reduction and catalytic conversion techniques in relation to aerial emissions from furnaces and vehicles. Site visits will be arranged where possible to enhance students' ability in application.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC4525. Pre-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515 or permission of the instructor.

courses.subject: EESC

Dr. ZHANG Li,   Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

courses.description: This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in global biogeochemistry. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering major elemental cycles from the early Earth to future projections and from the lithosphere to the atmosphere, with an emphasis on the Ocean. Advanced concepts of application of biogeochemistry will further be discussed with an emphasis on environmental pollution and global climate change. The fundamentals of major elemental cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, and silicate will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: 1) Pre-requisite: EESC/ESSC3020 or EESC/ESSC3220 or EESC3230 or EESC/ESSC3300 or EESC3510 or EESC3520 or EESC/ESSC3600 or EESC/ESSC3800. 2) Not for those taken ENSC/EESC3330.  3) Need basic knowledge in environmental science and chemistry.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Chemical Treatment Processes
courses.description: This course introduces the principles and applications of various chemical and physiochemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air and water pollution. It studies the processes of neutralization, oxidation-reduction, chemical precipitation, coagulation, flocculation, physical separation, absorption, adsorption, filtration, chemical disinfection, solvent extraction, fractional distillation and incineration. It also examines the applicabilities and limitations of such processes with reference to the treatment and recovery of toxic and hazardous chemical wastes. Site visits will be arranged to enhance students' ability in application.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC4535. Pre-requisite: EESC2515 or ENSC2515 or permission of the instructor.

courses.description: This course discusses the techniques and procedures of evaluating environmental consequences arising from human activities, with focus on their application in Hong Kong as prescribed under the Hong Kong Environmental Impact Assessment Ordinance, and its Technical Memorandum. Students are encouraged to take the laboratory course (EESC4342) together with the lecture in order to have a better integration of theories and practical experiences on the subject.

courses.description: This laboratory course accompanies the lecture course EESC4340 and provides hands-on exercises on selected techniques used in environmental impact assessment (EIA). Students will critically review a current EIA report with respect to its soundness in the application of EIA methodologies and the evaluation of assessment results. They will also gain first-hand experience on how to carry out an EIA by working on a small scale EIA project focusing on specific components of impact assessment.

meetings.instructor: Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

courses.description: This course introduces the contemporary problems and issues in environmentally dependent aspects of health. Broad coverage of health effects of foodborne, airborne and waterborne pollutants, pesticides, and consumer product are considered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENSC4250. Pre-requisite: EESC3520 or ENSC3520.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description: This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth and environmental sciences. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4510. Pre-requisite: (STAT1011 or 1012), and ((EESC2030 or ESSC2030) or PHYS2061).

courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science (such as atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere) and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling

meetings.instructor: Professor ZHAI Shixian
Professor ZHAI Shixian
Professor ZHAI Shixian

courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) and (MATH2550 or EESC2520 or PHYS2051) and (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113), or permission of instructor.

courses.subject: EESC

courses.description: This course gives students an opportunity to supplement what they have learnt from the major courses in the format of a local or overseas field trip during summer. Students are required to submit a proposal, participate actively in all activities throughout the field trip, submit an individual report and present a seminar for assessment. The field trip must be approved by the Programme.Students will learn as a global citizen how to learn from other countries’ experiences to act locally in environmental management and protection with innovative ideas and social responsibility. Students will also learn from social enterprise or non-government organizations how to work together with government officials and regular citizens to enhance conservation and environmental protection.

courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Soil Mechanics and Its Applications
courses.description: A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil; stress and strain; pore pressure, seepage theory and effective stress; elastic solutions; shear strength and Mohr-Coulomb theory; failure mode and criteria; soil consolidation; lateral earth pressure; slope stability; bearing capacity and foundation designs; pile analyses and designs; soil improvement and soil nailing. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.

courses.description: This course introduces concepts, principles, and applications of geophysical methods in environmental and engineering studies. It offers an overall survey of various geophysical methods for exploring the shallow subsurface. It provides the technical foundation needed to understand the use and limitations of gravity, seismic, ground penetrating radar, and electromagnetic methods. Demonstration of commonly used methods will be provided in the field along with tutorials of preliminary data analysis techniques. Technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals will be discussed in reading groups.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5110.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth System Science because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5120.

courses.description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer modeling. The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences or grant the approval from course coordinator;Pre-requisite(s): ESSC/EESC2010 and ESSC/EESC3100 or permission of instructor;Exclusion: EASC5130.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey and programming methods of data processing will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5140.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Volcanoes
courses.description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5150.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: What is the mechanism of plate tectonics and a variety of geological phenomena, such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting? Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. Lectures, paper discussions, and tutorials will help you to understand the principle of geodynamics, learn how to develop simple but useful models, and explain how the Earth evolves.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5170.

courses.title: Earthquake Source Physics

courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of earthquake source physics. The topics covered include seismic instrumentation, geophysical observations of earthquake source processes, kinematic source representation of earthquakes, dynamic rupture propagation of earthquakes, frictional properties of fault zones, and entire earthquake cycle. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5180.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Boundary-Layer Meteorology

meetings.instructor: Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald

courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; stability and boundary-layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5210.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Tropical Meteorology

meetings.instructor: Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Professor TAM Chi Yung Francis
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Professor TAM Chi Yung Francis
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Professor TAM Chi Yung Francis
Dr. AU-YEUNG Yee Man,   Professor TAM Chi Yung Francis

courses.description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, tropical ocean circulation, tropical weather, climate and atmosphere-ocean interaction phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5220.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
courses.description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5240.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Urban Climatology
courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5260

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Cloud Dynamics

meetings.instructor: Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo
Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo
Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald,   Professor LEUNG Wing Mo

courses.description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5270.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Meteorology
courses.description: Practical Meteorology is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of meteorology and their practical applications. The course will cover synoptic and mesoscale meteorology, satellite and radar meteorology, radiative transfer, lidar meteorology, aviation meteorology, and atmospheric instrumentation. Through a combination of lectures and case studies using instrument data, students will gain hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting meteorological data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5280.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Chemistry of Aquatic and Terrestrial Organic Matter

meetings.instructor: Professor CHOW Tat Shing

courses.description: The course "Chemistry of Aquatic and Terrestrial Organic Matter" covers the study of the chemical composition, properties, and reactivity of organic matter in aquatic and terrestrial environments. Students will learn about the sources, transformation, and fate of organic matter in natural systems, as well as the impact of human activities on organic matter cycling. Topics may include the structure and function of organic molecules, biogeochemical processes involving organic matter, analytical techniques for studying organic matter, and the role of organic matter in ecosystem functioning. This course may also explore the implications of organic matter chemistry for environmental quality, carbon cycling, and nutrient dynamics in natural systems. Advisory: 2 years college course works in Chemistry, Physics, and Mathematics is recommended.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Biogeochemistry

meetings.instructor: Dr. ZHANG Li,   Professor Benoit THIBODEAU
Dr. ZHANG Li,   Professor Benoit THIBODEAU
Dr. ZHANG Li,   Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

courses.description: This course presents the recent understanding and advancements in global biogeochemistry. The lectures are on a range of topics, covering major elemental cycles from the early Earth to future projections and from the lithosphere to the atmosphere, with an emphasis on the Ocean. Advanced concepts of application of biogeochemistry will further be discussed with an emphasis on environmental pollution and global climate change. The fundamentals of major elemental cycles like carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, oxygen, sulphur, and silicate will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences or MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences. There is a basic course requirement in which we expect students to have fundamental knowledge in environmental science and chemistry.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Environmental Health

meetings.instructor: Professor Benoit THIBODEAU

courses.description: This graduate-level course explores the interdisciplinary field of environmental health through the lens of systems thinking. Students will examine how ecological, social, and technological systems interact to influence public health. Emphasis is placed on understanding complex interconnections and developing holistic solutions to environmental health challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences or MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description: This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data. Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5510

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Numerical Methods and Modeling for Earth and Environmental Sciences

courses.description: This course covers the principles of numerical methods and modeling relevant for earth and environmental sciences applications. Topics include: optimization; interpolation; finite differencing; numerical solutions to ordinary and partial differential equations; programming numerical models; filtered models; boundary conditions; subgrid-scale processes; data assimilation; applications in earthquake, climate, air quality, weather forecast and groundwater models. Python will be used in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5520

courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science, such as the (atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere), and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5540.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling

meetings.instructor: Professor ZHAI Shixian
Professor ZHAI Shixian

courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5550.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Selected Topics in Earth and Environmental Sciences
courses.description: Recent research methods, experimental, and computational techniques applied in selected, advanced topics in Earth and Environmental Sciences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Environmental Sciences;Exclusion: EASC5602.

courses.subject: EESC
courses.title: Integrated Earth and Environmental Field Study
courses.description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC5709 covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. This course will train the postgraduate students to master basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.
